awd_titl_txt: Robotics Awake: Promoting the Diffusion of Innovation through Curriculum Development and a Technician Training Community College Extension Model
awd_abstract_narration:
Wake Technical Community College (Wake Tech) will collaborate with industry partners to develop curricula for training technicians in the operation, utilization, and programming of light industrial robots in advanced manufacturing applications.  This model enables the use of technician training as a basis for community college extension work to promote the diffusion of innovations likely to contribute to regional economic development. The project will impact the region through modernization and improved competitiveness of local manufacturers as well as by recruiting diverse students to learn advanced manufacturing skills.  The overarching goals of this ATE project will be achieved by: (a) building collaborations with industry partners, (b) developing and disseminating robotics education in advanced manufacturing curricula, (c) improving student learning, performance and industrial skill acquisition, and (d) developing a model for industrial extension through technician education. To achieve the goals of this project, Wake Tech will leverage relationships with over 70 local manufacturing companies, North Carolina State University, North Carolina Works, and employment agencies.  This program is designed to recruit and serve 120 students over the three year duration of the project. 

Project activities include (a) the creation of an industry partnership group focused on integration of co-robots in local manufacturing plants, (b) professional development for faculty from Wake Tech and three neighboring community colleges, (c) developing industrial extension partnerships, (d) development and implementation of two courses and certificates, (d) establishing equipment to support hands-on curricula, (e) recruiting diverse students though outreach efforts, and (f) developing and evaluating a model for future community college extension work. The project team and independent evaluator will conduct a case study of Wake Tech's role as a knowledge hub in the diffusion of the innovation of technician education in light industrial robots. This project will produce broader impacts through new curricula for students and collaboration with regional industry. The project will provide local and regional benefits by assisting local small to mid-size manufacturing businesses in increasing productivity and competitiveness with multiplier effects in the surrounding communities and nearby community colleges.

por.por_cntn:
The Robotics Awake: Promoting the Diffusion of Innovation through Curriculum Development and a Technician Training Community College Extension Model project was a four-year $575,277 National Science Foundation (NSF) ATE grant. The goal was to develop an educational program in co-robotics for advanced manufacturing that would support regional industry needs for highly skilled operators and programmers to work with emerging classes of robots. The field of robotics is actively innovating with growing potential to increase the competitiveness of U.S. manufacturing through increased productivity leading to new job creation (Robotics VO, 2013).  New capabilities along with increasing affordability give cobots enormous potential for increasing the competitiveness of small to mid-size manufacturing operations and make them ideal for the many smaller and more specialized manufacturing operations in our region.

This project produced new curricula and student certifications in collaboration with the regional Robotics industry and enhanced learning experiences through the acquisition of multi-manufactured robots. The project provides the necessary foundation from which further program enhancements can be developed to meet the rapidly expanding needs of advanced manufacturing and robotics and further enables the college?s participation in activities involving industry collaboration and science education.

The Robotics Awake program provided benefits assisting regional small and mid-size manufacturing businesses in increasing productivity and competitiveness with multiplier effects in the surrounding communities. Course replication is available for the benefit of community colleges throughout the state. The curricula developed and outreach activities were designed to serve a range of students. The project also leveraged an existing partnership with the NC Department of Commerce, NC Works, to recruit a racially and ethnically diverse population of under- and unemployed individuals to participate in the program.

This project allowed Wake Technical Community College to collaborate with industry partners, regional community colleges, and North Carolina State University to develop curricula for Workforce Continuing Education courses in operating and programming light collaborative robots (cobots) for manufacturing while developing a model for community college extension promoting the diffusion of innovation through technician education.

Major activities included: i) established an industry partnership group, ii) conducted a job task analysis focus group, iii) developed curricula for three collaborative robotics certificates, iv) received Governor?s Emergency Education Relief funds to assist student scholarships, v) acquired equipment, vi) became an Amazon mechatronics training partner, and vii) connected the program with the regional workforce development system.

The project team established formal partnerships with robot manufacturers and those using robots in manufacturing. Feedback obtained through quarterly Advisory Board meetings helped in the development of a task analysis, curricula, credentialing, and certifications. Three touring and equipment demonstrations introduced industry partners to the potential and benefits of robots.

The key skills, tasks, and knowledge identified in the job task analysis guided the development of three new courses and determined the need for three certifications (Collaborative Robotics Technician 1, Collaborative Robotics Technician 2, and Collaborative Robotics Programmer) due to the amount of knowledge and skills that must be learned. Industry-verified curricula was developed and approved by the State Board of Community Colleges and is available through the state?s Community College System Combined Course Library. Curriculum presentations, workshops, and dissemination events included:

  • ATE Conferences (2017, 2018, 2019, 2020)
  • NC Manufacturing Conferences (2017, 2018, 2019, 2020)
  • Collaborative Robots, Advanced Vision, and AI Conference (2019)
  • North Carolina Community College Adult Education Conference (2018)
  • Innovations League of Community Colleges Conference (2020)

Although the COVID-19 pandemic prevented the attainment of enrollment and completion goals; new robotic equipment was acquired to enhance learning experiences broadening students? knowledge and giving hands-on training on cobots. A case study of the diffusion of robotics within companies participating in the project provided a model for community college extension work.

Key findings from the case study of the diffusion of robotics within companies participating in the project to provide a model for community college extension work performed with this grant include:

  • Most companies are interested in using collaborative robots for quality inspection.
  • Companies are more likely to use collaborative robots if they have a workforce already familiar with engineering and robotics.
  • End users of collaborative robots are more likely to think collaborative robot use could result in workforce reduction.
  • Community colleges can develop their role as a collaborative robot knowledge hub by focusing on training and certification and providing demonstrations and simulations of the benefits of collaborative robots.
  • Community colleges can leverage their role as a collaborative robot knowledge hub to support industry growth and economic development by connecting with businesses and providing training and awareness of the benefits of collaborative robots by sharing best practices.

Other products that have resulted from the award include:

  • Wake Tech Career Focus magazine feature on Collaborative Robotics (2019)
  • HI-TEC poster presented co-authored by Michael Moore at NCMEP (2019)
  • Outreach card created (2018)

 


Last Modified: 10/21/2021
Modified by: Michael E Moore
